head.title: Structure and rheology of binary mixtures in shear flow

article.h1: Structure and rheology of binary mixtures in shear flow

span.span: Istituto Nazionale per la Fisica della Materia, UnitÃ di Salerno and Dipartimento di Fisica, UniversitÃ¡ di Salerno, 84081 Baronissi (Salerno), Italy.

Istituto Nazionale per la Fisica della Materia, UnitÃ di Bari and Dipartimento di Fisica, UniversitÃ di Bari, and Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Bari, via Amendola 173, 70126 Bari, Italy.

div.p: Results are presented for the phase separation process of a binary mixture subject to an uniform shear flow quenched from a disordered to a homogeneous ordered phase. The kinetics of the process is described in the context of the time-dependent Ginzburg-Landau equation with an external velocity term. The large-nğ‘›italic-nn approximation is used to study the evolution of the model in the presence of a stationary flow and in the case of an oscillating shear.

For stationary flow we show that the structure factor obeys a generalized dynamical scaling. The domains grow with different typical lengthscales Rxsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¥italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{x} and RâŸ‚subscriptğ‘…perpendicular-toitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{\perp} respectively in the flow direction and perpendicularly to it. In the scaling regime RâŸ‚âˆ¼tÎ±âŸ‚similar-tosubscriptğ‘…perpendicular-tosuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼perpendicular-toitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR_{\perp}\sim t^{\alpha_{\perp}} and Rxâˆ¼Î³â¢tÎ±xsimilar-tosubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ›¾superscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¥italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-gamma italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR_{x}\sim\gamma t^{\alpha_{x}} (with logarithmic corrections), Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma being the shear rate, with Î±x=5/4subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¥54italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\alpha_{x}=5/4 and Î±âŸ‚=1/4subscriptğ›¼perpendicular-to14italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\alpha_{\perp}=1/4. The excess viscosity Î”â¢Î·Î”ğœ‚Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta after reaching a maximum relaxes to zero as Î³-2â¢t-3/2superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ‘¡32italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{-2}t^{-3/2}. Î”â¢Î·Î”ğœ‚Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta and other observables exhibit log-time periodic oscillations which can be interpreted as due to a growth mechanism where stretching and break-up of domains cyclically occur.

In the case of an oscillating shear a cross-over phenomenon is observed: Initially the evolution is characterized by the same growth exponents as for a stationary flow. For longer times the phase separating structure cannot align with the oscillating drift and a different regime is entered with an isotropic growth and the same exponents of the case without shear.

The kinetics of phase separation of a disordered system quenched into a multiphase coexistence region has been extensively studied in the last years [1]. The main features of the process are well understood: After an early stage during which ordered domains of the equilibrium phases are formed the segregation proceeds in the late stage by coarsening of ordered regions according to the power law growth Râ¢(t)âˆ¼tÎ±similar-toğ‘…ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡ğ›¼italic-R OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR(t)\sim t^{\alpha} for the average domains size. In binary liquids, the existence of several regimes characterized by different exponents Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha, due to the presence of various growth mechanisms, is well established [2]. In these regimes the pair correlation function Câ¢(r,t)ğ¶ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( italic-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(r,t) verifies a dynamical scaling law according to which it can be written as Câ¢(r,t)â‰ƒfâ¢(r/R)similar-to-or-equalsğ¶ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘“ğ‘Ÿğ‘…italic-C OPEN:( italic-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-f OPEN:( italic-r MULOP:divide italic-R CLOSE:)C(r,t)\simeq f(r/R), where fâ¢(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥italic-f OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)f(x) is a scaling function [3].

Â¿From the theoretical point of view the most relevant progresses have been achieved in the framework of the continuous approach based on the Cahn-Hilliard equation with a Ginzburg-Landau free energy functional, the time dependent Ginzburg-Landau (TDGL) model. Within this approach, which neglects hydrodynamics, the properties of the phase-separation kinetics can be efficiently studied by means of numerical simulations or analytically in the context of approximate theories, among which the so-called large-nğ‘›italic-nn limit (one-loop approximation). For a vectorial system with an infinite number of components nğ‘›italic-nn, indeed, the TDGL model is exactly soluble. The one-loop approximation is known to provide a mean-field picture of the phase-separation process which captures the essence of the phenomenon at a semi-quantitative level [4].

In this paper we study the process of phase separation in a binary mixture subject to an uniform shear flow. When shear is applied to the system the time evolution is substantially different from that of ordinary spinodal decomposition. We consider both a stationary flow and an oscillating shear.

A stationary flow induces strong deformations of the domains formed after the quench [5, 6, 7], which become anisotropic and stretched along the flow direction. Consequently the growth rate along the flow is larger than in the other directions. In some experiments a power law increase of the typical size of the domains is observed and a value Î”â¢Î±=Î±x-Î±âŸ‚Î”ğ›¼subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¥subscriptğ›¼perpendicular-toDelta italic-alpha RELOP:equals italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta\alpha=\alpha_{x}-\alpha_{\perp} in the range 0.8Ã·10.81NUMBER:0.8 MULOP:divide NUMBER:10.8\div 1 for the difference between the exponents in the flow and in the shear directions is reported [8, 9]. Two dimensional molecular dynamic simulations find a slightly smaller value [10]. In other experimental realizations, when the shear is strong enough, stringlike domains have been observed to extend macroscopically in the direction of the flow [11] preventing complete phase separation. In general, the scaling behavior of sheared systems is not clearly understood and the very existence of a scaling regime in different experimental systems is questionable.

In a previous paper [12] we have shown that the numerical solution of the one-loop approximation to the TDGL model for phase separation under shear exhibits a generalized scaling symmetry characterized by Î”â¢Î±=1Î”ğ›¼1Delta italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Delta\alpha=1. In the scaling regime the structure factor and other observables exhibit the interesting feature of an oscillatory pattern which can be related to a mechanism of storing and dissipation of elastic energy where domains are stretched and broken cyclically. This new effect has been shown to persist up to the longest available time of our computation and represents the hallmark of a complex dynamical pattern induced by the presence of the shear. In a recent paper Rapapa and Bray [13], by solving asymptotically the one-loop equations, confirmed analytically the existence of a (multi)-scaling symmetry; in the long time limit, however, they do not recover the cyclical pattern described insofar and they infer â€™that the observed oscillations are slowly-decaying preasymptotic transientsâ€™. Since their solution is obtained in the infinite time limit, then, a reference theory for the description of this remarkable phenomenon is lacking.

Given that the one-loop approximation is a mean-field solution in spirit the natural question of its accuracy for the description of the original model arises. A numerical analysis of the exact TDGL model has been performed recently in [14] where it is shown that the global picture of the one-loop approximation is adequate. In particular the oscillatory pattern is recovered. The existence of a scaling symmetry and the determination of the related exponents, however, has not been clearly established numerically mainly due to finite size effects limitations. The actual value of the growth exponents can be inferred by scaling [13] or renormalization group [14] arguments to be Î±âŸ‚=1/3subscriptğ›¼perpendicular-to13italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3\alpha_{\perp}=1/3, as in the case without shear (we stress the fact that hydrodynamic effects are neglected in this model), and Î±x=4/3subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¥43italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3\alpha_{x}=4/3.

The shear also induces a peculiar rheological behavior. The break-up of the stretched domains liberates an energy which gives rise to an increase Î”â¢Î·Î”ğœ‚Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta of the viscosity [15, 16]. Experiments and simulations show that the excess viscosity Î”â¢Î·Î”ğœ‚Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta reaches a maximum at t=tmğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šitalic-t RELOP:equals italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt=t_{m} and then relaxes to smaller values. The maximum of the excess viscosity is expected to occur at a fixed Î³â¢tğ›¾ğ‘¡italic-gamma italic-t\gamma t and to scale as Î”â¢Î·â¢(tm)âˆ¼Î³-Î½similar-toÎ”ğœ‚subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsuperscriptğ›¾ğœˆDelta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta\eta(t_{m})\sim\gamma^{-\nu} [6, 8]. Simple scaling arguments predict Î½=2/3ğœˆ23italic-nu RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3\nu=2/3 [6], but different values have been reported [8]. All these features are adequately described by the TDGL already at the one-loop level.

In this paper we present a complete scenario of the behavior of the TDGL model for phase separation in a shear flow in the framework of the large-nğ‘›italic-nn approximation. The behavior of the system is studied along the whole time history, from the instant of the quench onward, both in the presence of a steady flow and in the case of an oscillating shear where interesting effects are undercovered. Results are presented for two and three dimensional systems.

This paper is schematically divided as follows: In Sec.2 we specify the model and introduce the one-loop approximation that will be studied thoroughly in the following Sections. Section 3 is devoted to the analysis of the behavior of the model subjected to a steady flow. In Sec.4 the dynamics in the presence of an oscillatory shear is considered. In Sec.5 we present a discussion of the results, debate some open problems and draw our conclusions.
The binary mixture is described at equilibrium by a Ginzburg-Landau free-energy

div.p: For vectorial systems with n>dğ‘›ğ‘‘italic-n RELOP:greater-than italic-dn>d (dğ‘‘italic-dd is the spatial dimensionality) topological defects are not stable [2]. For large nğ‘›italic-nn, therefore, domains of the equilibrium phases are, strictly speaking, absent. Nevertheless, since from the solution of the one-loop equations presented below it is possible to identify characteristic growing lengths Rxâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{x}(t) and RâŸ‚â¢(t)subscriptğ‘…perpendicular-toğ‘¡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{\perp}(t) in the flow and in the other directions it is natural to interpret these quantities as the trace of the domains size after the one-loop approximation procedure has been performed. In the following we will always use the word domains in this broad acception.
In this section we consider the case of a constant shear rate Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma. Eq.Â (7) can be formally integrated, yielding

section.h3: III.1 Analytic solution in the short and long time limit

div.p: The consistency conditionÂ (8) cannot be worked out along the whole time history of the system. For this reason in the following Sections the model Equations will be solved numerically both in d=2ğ‘‘2italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:2d=2 and d=3ğ‘‘3italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:3d=3. However the model can be solved in the short and long time limit.

For short times the linearized theory developed originally by Cahn and Hilliard [20] for the situation with Î³=0ğ›¾0italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\gamma=0 can be extended to the present case. This amounts to neglecting the quartic term in the local part of the free energyÂ (1) since in the initial high temperature state the order parameter is small. With this approximation the solution of Eq.Â (2) reads

semantics.annotation: italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals Delta italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end caligraphic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:) OPEN:[ caligraphic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:] italic-d italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 italic-T INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end caligraphic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:) italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end caligraphic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:) OPEN:[ caligraphic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:] italic-d italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-z

div.p: This approach applies to the original model and to the large-nğ‘›italic-nn approximation as well because non-linear terms are neglected. It is well known that the linear theory describes the very initial transient of the phase-separation process, when domains are still forming. In this time domain the behaviour of the system in the presence of the flow is more interesting than in the simple case of an immobile fluid. A plot of the structure factorÂ (15) is presented for a two-dimensional system in Fig.Â (1) for the case Î³=1ğ›¾1italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\gamma=1 and T=0ğ‘‡0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0. Initially, when domains are forming but the shear flow has not yet produced sensible effects, the structure factor evolves assuming the typical structure of a circular volcano, similarly to what happens in the case without shear. At Î³â¢tâ‰ƒ0.5similar-to-or-equalsğ›¾ğ‘¡0.5italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.5\gamma t\simeq 0.5 the anisotropy induced by the shear produces a deformation in the profile of the edge of the volcano from a ring-like geometry into an ellipse, whose major axis forms with the positive direction of the kysubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¦italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{y} axis an angle of approximatively 45osuperscript45ğ‘œNUMBER:45 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end45^{o} (see Fig.Â (1)). At the same time small dips start to develop in the edge at the ends of the axes of the ellipse and four peaks can be clearly observed at Î³â¢tâ‰ƒ2similar-to-or-equalsğ›¾ğ‘¡2italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:2\gamma t\simeq 2. As time goes by, the angle formed by the major axis of the ellipse with the kysubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¦italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{y}-direction decreases and the dips in the profile of Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) along the major axis develop until Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) almost consists of two separated foils, at Î³â¢tâ‰ƒ4similar-to-or-equalsğ›¾ğ‘¡4italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:4\gamma t\simeq 4, when a couple of peaks prevails. The same initial pattern is also observed [14] by numerically solving the full model equationÂ (2). At later times, however, the presence of the non-linear terms becomes fundamental and the linear theory breaks down, as in the case without shear. It is important to stress the fact that the presence of four peaks in the structure factor is exhibited already at the linear theory level of approximation. We will see in the following sections that the very existence of a multiply peaked Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) produces a rich dynamical pattern originating an oscillatory phenomenon.

The self-consistency conditionÂ (8) has been worked out explicitly in the long-time domain in [13]. It is found that the model is interested by a multiscaling symmetry, as in the case without shear [21], characterized by the growth of the characteristic lengthscales as

div.p: and

div.p: in the directions of the flow and perpendicular to it respectively. The excess viscosity and the normal stress differences behave as

Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t ARG:end ARG:start italic-t ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: The same behaviors (apart from logarithmic corrections) is obtained in [12] by means of a scaling ansatz.

We present in this Section the results of the numerical integration of the large-nğ‘›italic-nn equationÂ (7) which allows to follow the whole time history of the phase-separation process. We restrict ourselves to the case with T=0ğ‘‡0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0. An Euler first order discretization scheme has been implemented in d=2ğ‘‘2italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:2d=2 and d=3ğ‘‘3italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:3d=3 on dğ‘‘italic-dd-dimensional lattices with 201201NUMBER:201201 mesh points per each direction. For long times the structure factor is strongly peaked around typical wavevectors which move towards zero as time goes on (see Fig 2). Given that the support of Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) also shrinks to zero it is possible to greatly improve the quality of the numerical computation by using a self-adaptive mesh algorithm that follows the evolution of the support of the structure factor. We have solved Eq.Â (7) for various values of the shear rate Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma in the range [10-4,10-2]superscript104superscript102OPEN:[ NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:][10^{-4},10^{-2}]. We found that the qualitative behavior is the same for all the values of Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma considered. Â¿From the knowledge of the structure factor we compute the characteristic lengths Râ¢(t)ğ‘…ğ‘¡italic-R OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R(t) as

The behavior of Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) is shown in Fig.Â (2) for Î³=0.001ğ›¾0.001italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.001\gamma=0.001. Initially the evolution of the structure factor is resemblant to the one observed in Fig.Â (1) where the linear theory for Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) was plotted. Later on, however, the linear theory fails because the non-linearities become relevant, and the long-time regime is entered. This is characterized by the shrinking of the support of Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) towards the origin with different rates for the shear and the flow directions so that the tilt angle, namely the direction along which Cğ¶italic-CC is aligned, decreases in time. The structure factor is divided into two separated foils which are symmetric due to the property Câ¢(kâ†’,t)=Câ¢(-kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-C OPEN:( ADDOP:minus OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t)=C(-\vec{k},t). In each foil two distinct peaks can be observed located at (kx1,ky1)subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦1OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(k_{x_{1}},k_{y_{1}}) and (kx2,ky2)subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦2OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(k_{x_{2}},k_{y_{2}}) with |kx1|â‰ƒ2â¢|kx2|similar-to-or-equalssubscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥12subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥2VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:2 VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||k_{x_{1}}|\simeq 2|k_{x_{2}}| and |ky1|â‰ƒ2â¢|ky2|similar-to-or-equalssubscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦12subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦2VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:2 VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||k_{y_{1}}|\simeq 2|k_{y_{2}}|. Their heights change in time. The first peak to prevail is that located at (kx1,ky1)subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦1OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(k_{x_{1}},k_{y_{1}}), while the other peak dominates later. As time elapses the two peaks are observed to prevail alternatively. This oscillatory behavior continues up to the longest times of our computations.

In Fig.Â (3) the quantities (Î³â¢lnâ¡t)1/4â¢Rxâ¢(t)superscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡14subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ‘¡OPEN:( italic-gamma OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)(\gamma\ln t)^{1/4}R_{x}(t) and (Î³â¢lnâ¡t)1/4â¢Ryâ¢(t)superscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡14subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¦ğ‘¡OPEN:( italic-gamma OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)(\gamma\ln t)^{1/4}R_{y}(t) are plotted against the strain Î³â¢tğ›¾ğ‘¡italic-gamma italic-t\gamma t. According to Eqs.(16,17) for long times these quantities should collapse, for different values of the shear, on two power-law mastercurves with exponents 5/454NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:45/4 and 1/414NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:41/4, respectively. Here we observe that the collapse is indeed good, but the predicted power-law behavior is modulated by an oscillatory pattern. These oscillations are observed to be periodic on a log-time axis and persist up to the limit of the computational time.

We now consider the rheological behavior of the mixture by plotting in Fig.Â (4) the quantity (Î³/lnâ¡t)1/2â¢Î”â¢Î·â¢(t)superscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡12Î”ğœ‚ğ‘¡OPEN:( italic-gamma MULOP:divide OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Delta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)(\gamma/\ln t)^{1/2}\Delta\eta(t) against the strain. This quantity reaches a maximum at Î³â¢tâ‰ƒ3.5similar-to-or-equalsğ›¾ğ‘¡3.5italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:3.5\gamma t\simeq 3.5 and then decrease as also found in experiments [8]. For long times Eq.Â (18) would predict a data collapse for different Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma on a single power-law master-curve with exponent -3/232ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2-3/2. Here the situation is similar to the previous figure, in that the predicted behavior is modulated by log-time periodic oscillations. On the bases of simple scaling arguments the maximum of the excess viscosity Î”â¢Î·â¢(tm)Î”ğœ‚subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šDelta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta\eta(t_{m}) is expected to occur at a fixed Î³â¢tğ›¾ğ‘¡italic-gamma italic-t\gamma t and to scale as Î”â¢Î·â¢(tm)âˆ¼Î³-Î½similar-toÎ”ğœ‚subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsuperscriptğ›¾ğœˆDelta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta\eta(t_{m})\sim\gamma^{-
u}, with Î½=2/3ğœˆ23italic-nu RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3
u=2/3 [6, 8]. These arguments do not directly apply to the one-loop approximation since, due to the mean field nature, the exponents are different. The asymptotic solutionÂ (18) is not adequate to this early stage effect. The Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma dependence of Î”â¢Î·â¢(tm)Î”ğœ‚subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šDelta italic-eta OPEN:( italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta\eta(t_{m}) is plotted in the inset of Fig.Â 4 showing that a power-law behaviour with Î½â‰ƒ0.6similar-to-or-equalsğœˆ0.6italic-nu RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.6
u\simeq 0.6 is obeyed, in partial agreement with the aforementioned scaling arguments.

In Fig.Â (5) we report the numerical results for the first normal stress by plotting (Î³â¢lnâ¡t)-1/2â¢Î”â¢N1superscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡12Î”subscriptğ‘1OPEN:( italic-gamma OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(\gamma\ln t)^{-1/2}\Delta N_{1} against Î³â¢tğ›¾ğ‘¡italic-gamma italic-t\gamma t with Î³=0.01ğ›¾0.01italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.01\gamma=0.01. We find that Î”â¢N1â¢(t)Î”subscriptğ‘1ğ‘¡Delta italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\Delta N_{1}(t) scales asymptotically as predicted by Eq.Â (19) again modulated by an oscillatory pattern.

The periodic oscillations observed in all the physical observables are due to the competition between the different peaks of Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t). Letâ€™s refer to the behavior of the excess viscosity to understand how this competition affects the rheological quantities, using the features of the structure factor to obtain information about the domains evolution under the action of shear. Î”â¢Î·Î”ğœ‚Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta reaches its first maximum when the shape of Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) is such that the peak located at (kx1,ky1)subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦1OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(k_{x_{1}},k_{y_{1}}) prevails and the difference between the height of the two peaks is maximal. At this time the domains are elongated by the flow and there is a prevalence of thin domains in the system. As these string-like domains are stretched further, they eventually break up into two or more domains, dissipating the stored energy. This has two effects: the excess viscosity decreases and, on the other hand, the thick domains, which have not yet been broken, prevail. In this situation the other peak of Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) (which is located at (kx2,ky2)subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦2OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(k_{x_{2}},k_{y_{2}}) and represents the smaller features) grows faster until it prevails and Î”â¢Î·Î”ğœ‚Delta italic-eta\Delta\eta reaches a minimum. This behavior is reproduced with a characteristic frequency in log-time. Recently, a similar behavior has been observed in the numerical simulation of the full model EquationÂ (2) [14].

In this section we report the result of the numerical solution of Eq.Â (7) in d=3ğ‘‘3italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:3d=3. In Fig.Â (6) the time evolution of the structure factor in the special planes kx=0subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{x}=0, ky=0subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¦0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{y}=0 and kz=0subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘§0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{z}=0 is shown for Î³=0.001ğ›¾0.001italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.001\gamma=0.001. In the plane kz=0subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘§0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{z}=0 Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) behaves analogously to the previously discussed two dimensional case. In this Section we consider the case of a time-dependent shear rate with

In particular, at the end of the first oscillation, the four peaks of Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) are located at comparable distances from the origin of the kğ‘˜italic-kk-space differently from what observed in Fig.Â (2) at Î³â¢t=6ğ›¾ğ‘¡6italic-gamma italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:6\gamma t=6. This is shown in Fig.Â (9) where the configurations of the structure factor are shown at each quarter of oscillation of the shear rate in the asymptotic stage.

For small Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau, instead, Rxsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¥italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{x} and Rysubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¦italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{y} grow with the same exponent 1/414NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:41/4 from the beginning.

These observations suggest the following physical interpretation: for t<Ï„/2ğ‘¡ğœ2italic-t RELOP:less-than italic-tau MULOP:divide NUMBER:2t<\tau/2, since Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma does not change sign, the evolution of the blend is comparable to the case with a constant shear rate. In particular, if Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau is sufficiently large to exceed the initial stage when domains are forming, the power growth laws described in Sec.Â 3 for Rx,RâŸ‚subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘…perpendicular-toitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{x},R_{\perp} are observed with Î±x=5/4subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¥54italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\alpha_{x}=5/4 and Î±âŸ‚=1/4subscriptğ›¼perpendicular-to14italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\alpha_{\perp}=1/4. On timescales much longer then Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau, however, the network of the larger domains cannot be efficiently tilted along the flow orientation which changes periodically its sign. This is confirmed by the behaviour of the two peaks with |ky|â‰«|kx|much-greater-thansubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:much-greater-than VERTBAR:| italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||k_{y}|\gg|k_{x}| whose position in the kğ‘˜italic-kk-plane moves toward the origin but does not cross the kx=0subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{x}=0 plane, as it would be the case if the orientation of the domains corresponding to these peaks were reversed. In this situation the difference Î”â¢Î±=1Î”ğ›¼1Delta italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Delta\alpha=1 between the exponents in the flow and shear direction cannot be sustained, because the larger domains are not directed along the flow orientation at all times, and a growth law with the same exponent 1/4 in all the directions is obeyed. It is interesting to notice that the other peaks, which represent smaller domains formed by the break-up of the larger ones, crosses the ky=0subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¦0italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k_{y}=0 plane during their rotation every half period of Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma. This suggests that these features are tilted by the oscillating shear and follow the flow orientation. Then we expect to observe in a real blend two type of domains which respond differently to the oscillations of the flow: a network of large and elongated structures which maintains the orientation imposed during the first half period of Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma and a multitude of more isotropic features, generated by the break-up of strained regions, which oscillate following the flow.

The coefficient Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta in the r.h.s. of the Eq.Â (28) multiplies the portion of the shear stress in phase with the shear rate and represents the viscosity of a viscoelastic fluid. The integral of the second term of the r.h.s. of the Eq.Â (28) can be identified with the shear strain present in the mixture at time tğ‘¡italic-tt. The coefficient Gğºitalic-GG is therefore the effective elastic shear modulus of the fluid. Pure viscous behavior corresponds to G=0ğº0italic-G RELOP:equals NUMBER:0G=0 (Ï•=Ï€/2italic-Ï•ğœ‹2italic-phi RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2\phi=\pi/2), pure elastic behavior to Î·=0ğœ‚0italic-eta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\eta=0 (Ï•=0italic-Ï•0italic-phi RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\phi=0) [24].
In order to compute Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta and Gğºitalic-GG during the phase separation we calculated by numerical integration the shear stress using its general definitionÂ (9). By writing

div.p: it follows that Î·=Aâ¢(t)/Î³oğœ‚ğ´ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¾ğ‘œitalic-eta RELOP:equals italic-A OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\eta=A(t)/\gamma_{o} and G=Ï‰â¢Bâ¢(t)/Î³oğºğœ”ğµğ‘¡subscriptğ›¾ğ‘œitalic-G RELOP:equals italic-omega italic-B OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:endG=\omega B(t)/\gamma_{o}. In general, Ağ´italic-AA and Bğµitalic-BB depend on time. During a single shear oscillation, however, we expect that the Eq.Â (29) holds as a good approximation with constant values for Ağ´italic-AA and Bğµitalic-BB. In this way Ïƒxâ¢yâ¢(t)subscriptğœğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¡italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\sigma_{xy}(t) is expressed in terms of the first two coefficients in a Fourier series expansion over the interval of scaled time of duration 2â¢Ï€2ğœ‹NUMBER:2 italic-pi2\pi. The values we obtain may be referred to the time that locates the middle of the interval. Thus we get

In Fig.Â (12) we report the plots of Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta and Gğºitalic-GG against Î³oâ¢tsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘œğ‘¡italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t\gamma_{o}t. The viscosity shows a crossover between a power law decay with exponent -3/232ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2-3/2 at short times and an asymptotic behavior whose exponent is -1/212ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2-1/2. This can be explained observing that, for the steady shear case, the dynamic viscosity Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta coincides with the excess viscosity which scales with the inverse of the domains volume Vğ‘‰italic-VV. When an oscillatory shear is applied Vğ‘‰italic-VV crosses over from an initial power law increase Vâˆ¼t3/2similar-toğ‘‰superscriptğ‘¡32italic-V RELOP:similar-to italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV\sim t^{3/2}, similar to the one for the case with steady shear (see Fig. (3)), to a slower growth Vâˆ¼t1/2similar-toğ‘‰superscriptğ‘¡12italic-V RELOP:similar-to italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV\sim t^{1/2}, as already discussed above for Rxâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)R_{x}(t), producing a corresponding crossover in Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta.

Â¿From the computed values of Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta and Gğºitalic-GG we estimated the phase angle Ï•italic-Ï•italic-phi\phi, which, according to Eqs.Â (26) and (28), is given by Ï•=arctanâ¡(Î·Gâ¢Ï‰)italic-Ï•ğœ‚ğºğœ”italic-phi RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:inverse-tangent OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-eta ARG:end ARG:start italic-G ARG:end italic-omega CLOSE:)\displaystyle\phi=\arctan\Big{(}\frac{\eta}{G}\;\omega\Big{)}. In Fig.Â (13) we report the time evolution of Ï•italic-Ï•italic-phi\phi as a function of Î³oâ¢tsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘œğ‘¡italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t\gamma_{o}t. It can be seen that Ï•italic-Ï•italic-phi\phi decreases with time to reach an asymptotic value which is approximately 0.016. Accordingly, the system we are investigating shows in the asymptotic stage a behavior which is essentially elastic. The experimental data of [25] confirm this behavior.

In this paper we have studied the kinetics of a phase-separating binary fluid, in the presence of a shear flow, by means of the TDGL model. It is nowadays well established that the corresponding model with Î³=0ğ›¾0italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\gamma=0 accurately describes the main features of the segregation process in binary alloys, where hydrodynamics can be neglected. In viscous fluids, such as polymeric blends, the validity of the present approach is limited to the early stage of spinodal decomposition; for longer times one should consider the full hydrodynamic description [2].

When the shear is applied to a fluid the behavior of the system is profoundly changed under many respects and a general agreement on the predictivness of the proposed models is matter of general debate. A discussion on possible effects of hydrodynamics is presented in [3]. Moreover, the numerical solution of the TDGL model with shear poses serious problems due to discretization limitations and finite size effects and, although some progresses have been recently achieved [14], a satisfactory description is nowadays not available. In this scenario it is important to devise a simple analytical scheme providing the fundamental tools for the comprehension of the fluid dynamics. A natural choice in the field of growth kinetics is the large-nğ‘›italic-nn approximation, that has been thoroughly studied in the case without shear, where it has proven to give a reliable description of the segregation process, although at a mean field level.

In this paper the behavior of the TDGL model in the one-loop approximation is studied in detail, and the whole time evolution of the blend is considered, from the quenching instant onward; the cases of a stationary flow and of an oscillating shear have been examined. In doing so we undercover a very rich dynamical pattern, where not only some experimental findings are reproduced, but new predictions are allowed. After an early stage, which is accurately described by the linear theory Ã¡ la Cahn-Hilliard, the presence of the velocity field produces an anisotropic power-law growth of the characteristic lengths Rxsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¥italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{x}, RâŸ‚subscriptğ‘…perpendicular-toitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{\perp} respectively in the flow direction and perpendicularly to it. The value of the exponent Î±âŸ‚=1/4subscriptğ›¼perpendicular-to14italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\alpha_{\perp}=1/4 in the directions perpendicular to the flow is the same as in models with vectorial conserved order parameter without shear; although the actual value of this exponent is not expected to be accurate for real fluids (since, even without shear, the exponent obtained at the same level of approximation is known to corresponds to the Lifshitz-Slyozov exponent Î±=1/3ğ›¼13italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3\alpha=1/3 for scalar fields) a growth exponent Î±âŸ‚subscriptğ›¼perpendicular-toitalic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:perpendicular-to POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\alpha_{\perp} unaffected by the presence of shear has been obtained also by scaling [13] and renormalization group [14] arguments applied to the full model equations and is also measured in experiments [8]. Moreover a difference Î”â¢Î±=1Î”ğ›¼1Delta italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Delta\alpha=1 between the flow and shear exponents is also expected to be obtained by releasing the present approximation [13, 14] and is observed in some experiments. In the case of a stationary flow the anisotropic growth governed by these exponents is observed from the onset of the scaling regime onwards. The power law behavior of any observable is decorated by log-time periodic oscillations. These oscillations characterize the scaling regime up to the longest simulated time but they are not observed in the asymptotic solution presented in [13]. Given that log-time periodicity appears to be a rather common feature being observed, besides segregating fluids, during fracturing of heterogeneous solids [26, 27] and in stock market indices [28] for instance, it would then be interesting to devise an analytical approach to enlighten the origin of this new phenomenon at least in the present model.

In experiments with real fluid systems carried out by Laufer et al. [29] and, successively, by Mani et al. [30] and Migler et al. [31] a double overshoot in the time behavior of the viscosity and of the normal stress is observed and an interpretation in terms of break-up and recombination of the domains network is proposed. On the bases of our results it is plausible that this double overshoot represents the first part of a log-time periodic phenomenon which could be hopefully detected with a suitable experimental setup. In the model we have studied the oscillatory behaviour is due to the competition between the different maxima of a four-fold peaked structure factor. The presence of these maxima is interpreted is Sec.Â III B as due to the existence of different types of domains and the recurrent prevalence of each peak is suggested to be caused by the interplay between these kind of regions. A structure factor with four maxima has also been observed in polymer mixtures [31]; however to our knowledge the connection between the alternative dominance of the peaks of Câ¢(kâ†’,t)ğ¶â†’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡italic-C OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-k ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)C(\vec{k},t) and the overshoots observed in the viscosity and in the stresses has never been discussed insofar, perhaps due to insufficient resolution, although an experimental confirmation of this hypotheses would be desirable.

When an oscillating shear is present, the anisotropic regime discussed so far for the steady shear case crosses over to an isotropic growth when domains are fully developed. In this late stage, from the analysis of the behavior of the structure factor, we conjecture again the existence of two types of domains responding differently to the flow oscillations: the network of elongated structures keeps the orientation assumed during its formation in the early stage while small features generated by scission of strained parts oscillate in phase with the flow. In this late stage the growth kinetics is regulated by the same exponents as without flow. We are not aware of experiments reporting these features: It would be interesting to devise an experimental set-up for testing this prediction.
